Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 15, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
It begins with a countdown. On August 14th, 1947, a woman in Bombay goes into labor 
as the clock ticks towards midnight. Across India, people hold their breath 
for the declaration of independence after nearly two centuries of British 
occupation and rule. And at the stroke of midnight, a squirming infant and two new 
nations are born in perfect synchronicity. These events form the foundation 
of "Midnight’s Children," a dazzling novel by the British-Indian 
author Salman Rushdie. The baby who is the exact same age 
as the nation is Saleem Sinai, the novel’s protagonist. His narrative stretches over 
30 years of his life, jumping backwards and forwards in time 
to speculate on family secrets and deep-seated mysteries. These include the greatest enigma of all: 
Saleem has magic powers, and they’re somehow related 
to the time of his birth. And he’s not the only one. All children born in and around 
the stroke of midnight are imbued with extraordinary powers; like Parvati the Witch, 
a spectacular conjurer; and Saleem’s nemesis Shiva, 
a gifted warrior. With his powers of telepathy, Saleem forges connections with a 
vast network of the children of midnight— including a figure who can step 
through time and mirrors, a child who changes their gender 
when immersed in water, and multilingual conjoined twins. Saleem acts as a delightful guide 
to magical happenings and historical context alike. Although his birthday is a day 
of celebration, it also marks a turbulent period 
in Indian history. In 1948, the leader of the Indian 
independence movement, Mahatma Gandhi, was assassinated. Independence also coincided 
with Partition, which divided British-controlled India  into the two nations of India 
and Pakistan. This contributed to the outbreak of 
the Indo-Pakistani Wars in 1965 and 1971. Saleem touches on all this and more, tracing the establishment 
of Bangladesh in 1971 and the emergency rule of Indira Gandhi. This vast historical frame is one 
reason why "Midnight’s Children" is considered one of the most illuminating
works of postcolonial literature ever written. This genre typically addresses the 
experience of people living in colonized and formerly colonized countries, and explores the fallout through themes 
like revolution, migration, and identity. Rushdie, who like Saleem was born in 1947,
was educated in India and Britain, and is renowned for his cross-continental 
histories, political commentary, and magical realism. He enriches "Midnight’s Children" 
with a plethora of Indian and Pakistani cultural references, from family traditions to food, 
religion and folktales. Scribbling by night under the 
watchful eyes of his lover Padma, Saleem’s frame narrative echoes 
that of "1001 Nights," where a woman named Scheherazade 
tells her king a series of stories to keep herself alive. And as Saleem sees it, 1001 is “the number of night, of magic, 
of alternative realities.” Over the course of the novel, Rushdie dazzles us with 
multiple versions of reality. Sometimes, this is like reading 
a rollercoaster. Saleem narrates: “Who what am I? My answer: I am everyone everything whose being-in-
the-world affected was affected by mine. I am anything that happens 
after I’ve gone which would not have happened 
if I had not come. Nor am I particularly exceptional 
in this matter; each 'I,' every one of the now-six-
hundred-million-plus of us, contains a similar multitude. I repeat for the last time: to understand me, 
you’ll have to swallow a world.” Saleem’s narrative often has 
a breathless quality— and even as Rushdie depicts the 
cosmological consequences of a life, he questions the idea that we can ever 
condense history into a single narrative. His mind-bending plot and 
shapeshifting characters have garnered continuing 
fascination and praise. Not only did "Midnight’s Children" win 
the prestigious Man Booker Prize in its year of publication, but in a 2008 competition that pitted 
all 39 winners against each other, it was named the best of all the winners. In a masterpiece of epic proportions, Rushdie reveals that there 
are no singular truths— rather, it’s wiser to believe in several 
versions of reality at once, hold many lives in the 
palms of our hands, and experience multiple moments 
in a single stroke of the clock.

Options: A. Telepathy, B. Shape shifting, C. Predicting the future, D. Flight
Correct Option: A

**Transcript**:
It begins with a countdown. On August 14th, 1947, a woman in Bombay goes into labor 
as the clock ticks towards midnight. Across India, people hold their breath 
for the declaration of independence after nearly two centuries of British 
occupation and rule. And at the stroke of midnight, a squirming infant and two new 
nations are born in perfect synchronicity. These events form the foundation 
of "Midnight’s Children," a dazzling novel by the British-Indian 
author Salman Rushdie. The baby who is the exact same age 
as the nation is Saleem Sinai, the novel’s protagonist. His narrative stretches over 
30 years of his life, jumping backwards and forwards in time 
to speculate on family secrets and deep-seated mysteries. These include the greatest enigma of all: 
Saleem has magic powers, and they’re somehow related 
to the time of his birth. And he’s not the only one. All children born in and around 
the stroke of midnight are imbued with extraordinary powers; like Parvati the Witch, 
a spectacular conjurer; and Saleem’s nemesis Shiva, 
a gifted warrior. With his powers of telepathy, Saleem forges connections with a 
vast network of the children of midnight— including a figure who can step 
through time and mirrors, a child who changes their gender 
when immersed in water, and multilingual conjoined twins. Saleem acts as a delightful guide 
to magical happenings and historical context alike. Although his birthday is a day 
of celebration, it also marks a turbulent period 
in Indian history. In 1948, the leader of the Indian 
independence movement, Mahatma Gandhi, was assassinated. Independence also coincided 
with Partition, which divided British-controlled India  into the two nations of India 
and Pakistan. This contributed to the outbreak of 
the Indo-Pakistani Wars in 1965 and 1971. Saleem touches on all this and more, tracing the establishment 
of Bangladesh in 1971 and the emergency rule of Indira Gandhi. This vast historical frame is one 
reason why "Midnight’s Children" is considered one of the most illuminating
works of postcolonial literature ever written. This genre typically addresses the 
experience of people living in colonized and formerly colonized countries, and explores the fallout through themes 
like revolution, migration, and identity. Rushdie, who like Saleem was born in 1947,
was educated in India and Britain, and is renowned for his cross-continental 
histories, political commentary, and magical realism. He enriches "Midnight’s Children" 
with a plethora of Indian and Pakistani cultural references, from family traditions to food, 
religion and folktales. Scribbling by night under the 
watchful eyes of his lover Padma, Saleem’s frame narrative echoes 
that of "1001 Nights," where a woman named Scheherazade 
tells her king a series of stories to keep herself alive. And as Saleem sees it, 1001 is “the number of night, of magic, 
of alternative realities.” Over the course of the novel, Rushdie dazzles us with 
multiple versions of reality. Sometimes, this is like reading 
a rollercoaster. Saleem narrates: “Who what am I? My answer: I am everyone everything whose being-in-
the-world affected was affected by mine. I am anything that happens 
after I’ve gone which would not have happened 
if I had not come. Nor am I particularly exceptional 
in this matter; each 'I,' every one of the now-six-
hundred-million-plus of us, contains a similar multitude. I repeat for the last time: to understand me, 
you’ll have to swallow a world.” Saleem’s narrative often has 
a breathless quality— and even as Rushdie depicts the 
cosmological consequences of a life, he questions the idea that we can ever 
condense history into a single narrative. His mind-bending plot and 
shapeshifting characters have garnered continuing 
fascination and praise. Not only did "Midnight’s Children" win 
the prestigious Man Booker Prize in its year of publication, but in a 2008 competition that pitted 
all 39 winners against each other, it was named the best of all the winners. In a masterpiece of epic proportions, Rushdie reveals that there 
are no singular truths— rather, it’s wiser to believe in several 
versions of reality at once, hold many lives in the 
palms of our hands, and experience multiple moments 
in a single stroke of the clock.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Consider the spot where you’re sitting. Travel backwards in time and it might’ve been submerged at 
the bottom of a shallow sea, buried under miles of rock, or floating through a molten, 
infernal landscape. But go back far enough— about 4.6 billion years, and you’d be in the middle of an enormous 
cloud of dust and gas orbiting a newborn star. This is the setting for some of the 
biggest, smallest mysteries of physics: the mysteries of cosmic dust bunnies. Seemingly empty regions 
of space between stars actually contain clouds of gas and dust, usually blown there by supernovas. When a dense cloud reaches a certain 
threshold called the Jeans mass, it collapses in on itself. The shrinking cloud rotates faster 
and faster, and heats up, eventually becoming hot enough to burn 
hydrogen in its core. At this point a star is born. As fusion begins in the new star, it sends out jets of gas that blow 
off the top and bottom of the cloud, leaving behind an orbiting ring of gas 
and dust called a protoplanetary disk. This is a surprisingly windy place; eddies of gas carry particles apart, 
and send them smashing into each other. The dust consists of tiny metal fragments,
bits of rock, and, further out, ices. We’ve observed thousands of these disks 
in the sky, at various stages of development as dust clumps together
into larger and larger masses. Dust grains 100 times smaller than the 
width of a human hair stick to each other through what’s called 
the van der Waals force. That’s where a cloud of electrons 
shifts to one side of a molecule, creating a negative charge on one end, 
and a positive charge on the other. Opposites attract, but van der Waals can 
only hold tiny things together. And there’s a problem: once dust 
clusters grow to a certain size, the windy atmosphere of a disk should 
constantly break them up as they crash into each other. The question of how they continue to grow
is the first mystery of dust bunnies. One theory looks to electrostatic charge 
to answer this. Energetic gamma rays, x-rays, 
and UV photons knock electrons off of gas 
atoms within the disk, creating positive ions 
and negative electrons. Electrons run into and stick to dust, making it negatively charged. Now, when the wind pushes 
clusters together, like repels like 
and slows them down as they collide. With gentle collisions 
they won’t fragment, but if the repulsion is too strong, 
they’ll never grow. One theory suggests that high energy 
particles can knock more electrons off of some 
dust clumps, leaving them positively charged. Opposites again attract, 
and clusters grow rapidly. But before long we reach 
another set of mysteries. We know from evidence found in meteorites that these fluffy dust bunnies 
eventually get heated, melted and then cooled into solid 
pellets called chondrules. And we have no idea how 
or why that happens. Furthermore, once those pellets do form,
how do they stick together? The electrostatic forces from before 
are too weak, and small rocks can’t be held together 
by gravity either. Gravity increases proportionally to the 
mass of the objects involved. That’s why you could effortlessly escape 
an asteroid the size of a small mountain using just the force generated 
by your legs. So if not gravity, then what? Perhaps it’s dust. A fluffy dust rim collected around the 
outside of the pellets could act like Velcro. There’s evidence for this in meteors, where we find many chondrules surrounded
by a thin rim of very fine material– possibly condensed dust. Eventually the chondrule pellets get 
cemented together inside larger rocks, which at about 1 kilometer across are finally large enough to hold 
themselves together through gravity. They continue to collide and grow 
into larger and larger bodies, including the planets we know today. Ultimately, the seeds of 
everything familiar– the size of our planet, its position 
within the solar system, and its elemental composition– were determined by an uncountably large 
series of random collisions. Change the dust cloud just a bit, and perhaps the conditions wouldn’t 
have been right for the formation of life on our planet.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How long ago did our solar system form?
Options: A. 460 years ago, B. 4,600 years ago, C. 4.6 million years ago, D. 4.6 billion years ago
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated age of the enormous cloud of dust and gas that our solar system formed from? Options: A. 3.6 billion years, B. 4.6 billion years, C. 5.6 billion years, D. 6.6 billion years Correct Option: B
Question 2: Describe the process by which a star is born from a dense cloud of gas and dust. Options: A. The cloud expands and cools, eventually becoming hot enough to burn helium in its core., B. The cloud collapses in on itself, rotates faster, and heats up, eventually becoming hot enough to burn hydrogen in its core., C. The cloud remains static and unchanged, eventually becoming hot enough to burn hydrogen in its core., D. The cloud disappears and reappears as a fully formed star. Correct Option: B
Question 3: If you were to travel to a protoplanetary disk, what would you expect to find in terms of the environment? Options: A. A calm and peaceful atmosphere, B. A surprisingly windy place with eddies of gas carrying particles apart, C. A completely empty and barren landscape, D. A frozen and icy environment Correct Option: B
Question 4: What force is responsible for holding tiny dust grains together in a protoplanetary disk? Options: A. Gravity, B. Electrostatic charge, C. Van der Waals force, D. Friction Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the problem with dust clusters growing to a certain size in a protoplanetary disk? Options: A. They become too heavy and collapse in on themselves, B. They are constantly broken up by the windy atmosphere as they crash into each other, C. They become too small and are blown away by the wind, D. They become too hot and melt Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is one theory that attempts to explain how dust clusters continue to grow despite the windy atmosphere? Options: A. Electrostatic charge causes like to repel like, slowing down collisions and preventing fragmentation, B. Gravity becomes stronger as the clusters grow, holding them together, C. The van der Waals force becomes stronger as the clusters grow, holding them together, D. The wind dies down as the clusters grow, allowing them to stick together Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the name given to the solid pellets that form from the fluffy dust bunnies after they are heated, melted, and cooled? Options: A. Chondrules, B. Meteorites, C. Asteroids, D. Planets Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is one possible explanation for how chondrule pellets stick together to form larger rocks? Options: A. Electrostatic forces hold them together, B. Gravity holds them together, C. A fluffy dust rim collected around the outside of the pellets acts like Velcro, D. Friction holds them together Correct Option: C
Question 9: At what size do rocks become large enough to hold themselves together through gravity? Options: A. 100 meters across, B. 1 kilometer across, C. 10 kilometers across, D. 100 kilometers across Correct Option: B
Question 10: What can be said about the formation of our planet and the conditions necessary for life to emerge? Options: A. The conditions were predetermined and guaranteed to produce life, B. The conditions were completely random and had no impact on the emergence of life, C. The conditions were determined by an uncountably large series of random collisions, and changing the dust cloud even slightly might have prevented the emergence of life, D. The conditions were identical to those of every other planet in the solar system Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (asking about the age of the solar system's formation), options (providing different time scales), and content (focusing on the formation of the solar system). The correct option in Question 1 (B. 4.6 billion years) also matches the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (D. 4.6 billion years ago).

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Consider the spot where you’re sitting. Travel backwards in time and it might’ve been submerged at 
the bottom of a shallow sea, buried under miles of rock, or floating through a molten, 
infernal landscape. But go back far enough— about 4.6 billion years, and you’d be in the middle of an enormous 
cloud of dust and gas orbiting a newborn star. This is the setting for some of the 
biggest, smallest mysteries of physics: the mysteries of cosmic dust bunnies. Seemingly empty regions 
of space between stars actually contain clouds of gas and dust, usually blown there by supernovas. When a dense cloud reaches a certain 
threshold called the Jeans mass, it collapses in on itself. The shrinking cloud rotates faster 
and faster, and heats up, eventually becoming hot enough to burn 
hydrogen in its core. At this point a star is born. As fusion begins in the new star, it sends out jets of gas that blow 
off the top and bottom of the cloud, leaving behind an orbiting ring of gas 
and dust called a protoplanetary disk. This is a surprisingly windy place; eddies of gas carry particles apart, 
and send them smashing into each other. The dust consists of tiny metal fragments,
bits of rock, and, further out, ices. We’ve observed thousands of these disks 
in the sky, at various stages of development as dust clumps together
into larger and larger masses. Dust grains 100 times smaller than the 
width of a human hair stick to each other through what’s called 
the van der Waals force. That’s where a cloud of electrons 
shifts to one side of a molecule, creating a negative charge on one end, 
and a positive charge on the other. Opposites attract, but van der Waals can 
only hold tiny things together. And there’s a problem: once dust 
clusters grow to a certain size, the windy atmosphere of a disk should 
constantly break them up as they crash into each other. The question of how they continue to grow
is the first mystery of dust bunnies. One theory looks to electrostatic charge 
to answer this. Energetic gamma rays, x-rays, 
and UV photons knock electrons off of gas 
atoms within the disk, creating positive ions 
and negative electrons. Electrons run into and stick to dust, making it negatively charged. Now, when the wind pushes 
clusters together, like repels like 
and slows them down as they collide. With gentle collisions 
they won’t fragment, but if the repulsion is too strong, 
they’ll never grow. One theory suggests that high energy 
particles can knock more electrons off of some 
dust clumps, leaving them positively charged. Opposites again attract, 
and clusters grow rapidly. But before long we reach 
another set of mysteries. We know from evidence found in meteorites that these fluffy dust bunnies 
eventually get heated, melted and then cooled into solid 
pellets called chondrules. And we have no idea how 
or why that happens. Furthermore, once those pellets do form,
how do they stick together? The electrostatic forces from before 
are too weak, and small rocks can’t be held together 
by gravity either. Gravity increases proportionally to the 
mass of the objects involved. That’s why you could effortlessly escape 
an asteroid the size of a small mountain using just the force generated 
by your legs. So if not gravity, then what? Perhaps it’s dust. A fluffy dust rim collected around the 
outside of the pellets could act like Velcro. There’s evidence for this in meteors, where we find many chondrules surrounded
by a thin rim of very fine material– possibly condensed dust. Eventually the chondrule pellets get 
cemented together inside larger rocks, which at about 1 kilometer across are finally large enough to hold 
themselves together through gravity. They continue to collide and grow 
into larger and larger bodies, including the planets we know today. Ultimately, the seeds of 
everything familiar– the size of our planet, its position 
within the solar system, and its elemental composition– were determined by an uncountably large 
series of random collisions. Change the dust cloud just a bit, and perhaps the conditions wouldn’t 
have been right for the formation of life on our planet.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A star is born when
Options: A. A gas cloud become dense enough to collapse, B. A collapsing dust cloud becomes hot enough to burn hydrogen, C. Jets blow away the free gas and dust in a dust cloud, D. Supernovas blow gas and dust together into a big pile
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated age of the enormous cloud of dust and gas that our solar system formed from? Options: A. 3.6 billion years, B. 4.6 billion years, C. 5.6 billion years, D. 6.6 billion years Correct Option: B
Question 2: Describe the process by which a star is born from a dense cloud of gas and dust. Options: A. The cloud expands and cools, eventually becoming hot enough to burn helium in its core., B. The cloud collapses in on itself, rotates faster, and heats up, eventually becoming hot enough to burn hydrogen in its core., C. The cloud remains static and unchanged, eventually becoming hot enough to burn hydrogen in its core., D. The cloud disappears and reappears as a fully formed star. Correct Option: B
Question 3: If you were to travel to a protoplanetary disk, what would you expect to find in terms of the environment? Options: A. A calm and peaceful atmosphere, B. A surprisingly windy place with eddies of gas carrying particles apart, C. A completely empty and barren landscape, D. A frozen and icy environment Correct Option: B
Question 4: What force is responsible for holding tiny dust grains together in a protoplanetary disk? Options: A. Gravity, B. Electrostatic charge, C. Van der Waals force, D. Friction Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the problem with dust clusters growing to a certain size in a protoplanetary disk? Options: A. They become too heavy and collapse in on themselves, B. They are constantly broken up by the windy atmosphere as they crash into each other, C. They become too small and are blown away by the wind, D. They become too hot and melt Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is one theory that attempts to explain how dust clusters continue to grow despite the windy atmosphere? Options: A. Electrostatic charge causes like to repel like, slowing down collisions and preventing fragmentation, B. Gravity becomes stronger as the clusters grow, holding them together, C. The van der Waals force becomes stronger as the clusters grow, holding them together, D. The wind dies down as the clusters grow, allowing them to stick together Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the name given to the solid pellets that form from the fluffy dust bunnies after they are heated, melted, and cooled? Options: A. Chondrules, B. Meteorites, C. Asteroids, D. Planets Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is one possible explanation for how chondrule pellets stick together to form larger rocks? Options: A. Electrostatic forces hold them together, B. Gravity holds them together, C. A fluffy dust rim collected around the outside of the pellets acts like Velcro, D. Friction holds them together Correct Option: C
Question 9: At what size do rocks become large enough to hold themselves together through gravity? Options: A. 100 meters across, B. 1 kilometer across, C. 10 kilometers across, D. 100 kilometers across Correct Option: B
Question 10: What can be said about the formation of our planet and the conditions necessary for life to emerge? Options: A. The conditions were predetermined and guaranteed to produce life, B. The conditions were completely random and had no impact on the emergence of life, C. The conditions were determined by an uncountably large series of random collisions, and changing the dust cloud even slightly might have prevented the emergence of life, D. The conditions were identical to those of every other planet in the solar system Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, as it asks about the process of star birth from a dense cloud of gas and dust. The correct option (B) in Question 2 also matches the correct option (B) in the ground truth MCQ, describing the process of the cloud collapsing, rotating faster, and heating up until it becomes hot enough to burn hydrogen in its core. 

While the wording and format of the two questions are not identical, the content and intent are similar enough to make Question 2 the most suitable match for the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Consider the spot where you’re sitting. Travel backwards in time and it might’ve been submerged at 
the bottom of a shallow sea, buried under miles of rock, or floating through a molten, 
infernal landscape. But go back far enough— about 4.6 billion years, and you’d be in the middle of an enormous 
cloud of dust and gas orbiting a newborn star. This is the setting for some of the 
biggest, smallest mysteries of physics: the mysteries of cosmic dust bunnies. Seemingly empty regions 
of space between stars actually contain clouds of gas and dust, usually blown there by supernovas. When a dense cloud reaches a certain 
threshold called the Jeans mass, it collapses in on itself. The shrinking cloud rotates faster 
and faster, and heats up, eventually becoming hot enough to burn 
hydrogen in its core. At this point a star is born. As fusion begins in the new star, it sends out jets of gas that blow 
off the top and bottom of the cloud, leaving behind an orbiting ring of gas 
and dust called a protoplanetary disk. This is a surprisingly windy place; eddies of gas carry particles apart, 
and send them smashing into each other. The dust consists of tiny metal fragments,
bits of rock, and, further out, ices. We’ve observed thousands of these disks 
in the sky, at various stages of development as dust clumps together
into larger and larger masses. Dust grains 100 times smaller than the 
width of a human hair stick to each other through what’s called 
the van der Waals force. That’s where a cloud of electrons 
shifts to one side of a molecule, creating a negative charge on one end, 
and a positive charge on the other. Opposites attract, but van der Waals can 
only hold tiny things together. And there’s a problem: once dust 
clusters grow to a certain size, the windy atmosphere of a disk should 
constantly break them up as they crash into each other. The question of how they continue to grow
is the first mystery of dust bunnies. One theory looks to electrostatic charge 
to answer this. Energetic gamma rays, x-rays, 
and UV photons knock electrons off of gas 
atoms within the disk, creating positive ions 
and negative electrons. Electrons run into and stick to dust, making it negatively charged. Now, when the wind pushes 
clusters together, like repels like 
and slows them down as they collide. With gentle collisions 
they won’t fragment, but if the repulsion is too strong, 
they’ll never grow. One theory suggests that high energy 
particles can knock more electrons off of some 
dust clumps, leaving them positively charged. Opposites again attract, 
and clusters grow rapidly. But before long we reach 
another set of mysteries. We know from evidence found in meteorites that these fluffy dust bunnies 
eventually get heated, melted and then cooled into solid 
pellets called chondrules. And we have no idea how 
or why that happens. Furthermore, once those pellets do form,
how do they stick together? The electrostatic forces from before 
are too weak, and small rocks can’t be held together 
by gravity either. Gravity increases proportionally to the 
mass of the objects involved. That’s why you could effortlessly escape 
an asteroid the size of a small mountain using just the force generated 
by your legs. So if not gravity, then what? Perhaps it’s dust. A fluffy dust rim collected around the 
outside of the pellets could act like Velcro. There’s evidence for this in meteors, where we find many chondrules surrounded
by a thin rim of very fine material– possibly condensed dust. Eventually the chondrule pellets get 
cemented together inside larger rocks, which at about 1 kilometer across are finally large enough to hold 
themselves together through gravity. They continue to collide and grow 
into larger and larger bodies, including the planets we know today. Ultimately, the seeds of 
everything familiar– the size of our planet, its position 
within the solar system, and its elemental composition– were determined by an uncountably large 
series of random collisions. Change the dust cloud just a bit, and perhaps the conditions wouldn’t 
have been right for the formation of life on our planet.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Tiny dust particles stick together through
Options: A. Gravity, B. Velcro-like adhesives, C. Van Der Waals forces, D. The strong force
Correct Option: C

Question: How big does an object have to grow before it can be held together by gravity?
Options: A. 1 km – about the size of an asteroid, B. 1 m – about the size of a meteoroid, C. 10,000 km – about the size of the Earth, D. 1000 km – about the size of a dwarf planet
Correct Option: A

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The dust in a protoplanetary disk becomes charged by
Options: A. Collecting electrons from the ionized gas, B. Collecting ions from the ionized gas, C. Energetic photons knocking electrons off the dust, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the estimated age of the enormous cloud of dust and gas that our solar system formed from? Options: A. 3.6 billion years, B. 4.6 billion years, C. 5.6 billion years, D. 6.6 billion years Correct Option: B
Question 2: Describe the process by which a star is born from a dense cloud of gas and dust. Options: A. The cloud expands and cools, eventually becoming hot enough to burn helium in its core., B. The cloud collapses in on itself, rotates faster, and heats up, eventually becoming hot enough to burn hydrogen in its core., C. The cloud remains static and unchanged, eventually becoming hot enough to burn hydrogen in its core., D. The cloud disappears and reappears as a fully formed star. Correct Option: B
Question 3: If you were to travel to a protoplanetary disk, what would you expect to find in terms of the environment? Options: A. A calm and peaceful atmosphere, B. A surprisingly windy place with eddies of gas carrying particles apart, C. A completely empty and barren landscape, D. A frozen and icy environment Correct Option: B
Question 4: What force is responsible for holding tiny dust grains together in a protoplanetary disk? Options: A. Gravity, B. Electrostatic charge, C. Van der Waals force, D. Friction Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the problem with dust clusters growing to a certain size in a protoplanetary disk? Options: A. They become too heavy and collapse in on themselves, B. They are constantly broken up by the windy atmosphere as they crash into each other, C. They become too small and are blown away by the wind, D. They become too hot and melt Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is one theory that attempts to explain how dust clusters continue to grow despite the windy atmosphere? Options: A. Electrostatic charge causes like to repel like, slowing down collisions and preventing fragmentation, B. Gravity becomes stronger as the clusters grow, holding them together, C. The van der Waals force becomes stronger as the clusters grow, holding them together, D. The wind dies down as the clusters grow, allowing them to stick together Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the name given to the solid pellets that form from the fluffy dust bunnies after they are heated, melted, and cooled? Options: A. Chondrules, B. Meteorites, C. Asteroids, D. Planets Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is one possible explanation for how chondrule pellets stick together to form larger rocks? Options: A. Electrostatic forces hold them together, B. Gravity holds them together, C. A fluffy dust rim collected around the outside of the pellets acts like Velcro, D. Friction holds them together Correct Option: C
Question 9: At what size do rocks become large enough to hold themselves together through gravity? Options: A. 100 meters across, B. 1 kilometer across, C. 10 kilometers across, D. 100 kilometers across Correct Option: B
Question 10: What can be said about the formation of our planet and the conditions necessary for life to emerge? Options: A. The conditions were predetermined and guaranteed to produce life, B. The conditions were completely random and had no impact on the emergence of life, C. The conditions were determined by an uncountably large series of random collisions, and changing the dust cloud even slightly might have prevented the emergence of life, D. The conditions were identical to those of every other planet in the solar system Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Hercules, 
the strongest man alive with a mighty heart to match. Orpheus, 
charmer of nature and master of music. Castor and Pollux, 
the twin tricksters hatched from an egg. The Boreads, 
sons of the North Wind who could hurtle through the air. For untold times 
these heroes had roamed ancient Greece, creating new legends wherever they went. But none of their adventures 
was so great as when they joined forces for the sake of a young man named Jason. Years before, Jason’s uncle Pelias 
had ruthlessly usurped the throne of Thessaly 
from Jason’s grandfather. When Jason returned 
to his father’s stolen court, the cowardly king 
set him a seemingly impossible task: cross the teeming seas to Colchis, and steal 
the golden fleece of a flying ram under King Aeetes’ nose. If Jason retrieved the Fleece, Pelias promised to relinquish the throne. Touched by his heroic mission, the Gods spread Jason’s call for help, and soon 
he had assembled a not-so-motley crew. These heroes, alongside countless sailors,
soothsayers, and rebel demigods, named themselves 
the Argonauts after their sturdy ship. But the path ahead 
was marked with untold terrors– enough to test even the fiercest heroes. Their first stop was Lemnos, an isle of women 
who had killed all the island’s men. As punishment, Aphrodite had cursed them
with a sickening stench– but that didn’t stop Jason 
fathering twins with the queen. The rest of the crew also found themselves
embroiled in new romances; until Hercules chastised them 
for not behaving like heroes. Eventually, 
they sailed on to the Mount of Bears, an island where a group of ancient, 
six-armed monsters lived alongside the peaceful Doliones. While the clan welcomed 
the Argonauts with open arms, the monsters surged down 
from the mountains and hurled rocks at the docked ship. Hercules held them off single-handedly, before his comrades joined the fray. Bolstered by their victory, 
the triumphant heroes sailed onward– only to be blown back 
to the island several stormy nights later. In the tempest, the Doliones 
thought these new arrivals invaders. The Argonauts were similarly unaware 
of their surroundings, and fought blunderingly in the dark, 
slaying wave after wave of foe. But the morning light 
revealed a horrible truth: their victims 
were none other than their previous hosts. Yet again, Jason had allowed the crew 
to be distracted, this time at a terrible cost. Ashamed at his conduct, he resolved 
to focus only on the Fleece, but even this haste proved ruinous. When Hercules’ squire 
was abducted by a water nymph, Jason sailed on– oblivious to the absence 
of his most powerful crewmate. The remaining Argonauts 
continued their quest, until stopping at the sight of an old man 
surrounded by a swirl of harpies. This was Phineas, 
a seer cursed by Zeus to endure 
old age, blindness, and endless torture for giving away 
his prophecies. Moved by his plight, 
the wind brothers set upon the flock, providing Phineas 
with a brief respite from his punishment. In return, the seer told them how to overcome
the terrifying trial that lay ahead: the Symplegades, a pair clashing rocks 
that reduced ships to splinters. But first, the Argonauts would have to maneuver 
past the mouth of hell, around the island 
of the bloodthirsty Amazons, and under psychedelic skies. These adventures cost the crew 
both in men and morale– and some feared 
they might be losing their minds. Upon reaching the clashing rocks, 
the exhausted crew quaked with fear. But Phineas’ advice rang in their heads. The Argonauts released a single dove and sped through in its wake 
to emerge unscathed. With this narrow escape, the Argonauts 
finally had Colchis in their sights. Yet while Jason rested 
and celebrated with his crew, he could feel his time 
among them was drawing to a close. As the fleece gleamed in his mind, he knew 
he would have to retrieve it alone. But he could not guess 
that this final task would have the most horrible price of all.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Argonauts were named after:
Options: A. Their motto, B. Their ship, C. A god, D. Their carpenter
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was the young man that the heroes joined forces for, and what was his mission? Options: A. Jason, to cross the seas to Colchis and steal the golden fleece, B. Hercules, to defeat the monsters on the Mount of Bears, C. Orpheus, to charm the harpies surrounding Phineas, D. Castor, to retrieve the throne of Thessaly Correct Option: A
Question 2: What was the curse placed upon the women of Lemnos by Aphrodite? Options: A. They were turned into monsters, B. They were cursed with a sickening stench, C. They were made to be infertile, D. They were forced to live on the Mount of Bears Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the outcome of the Argonauts' battle with the Doliones, and what did they realize the next morning? Options: A. They emerged victorious, but realized they had fought their previous hosts, B. They were defeated, but realized they had fought a group of monsters, C. They emerged victorious, but realized they had fought a group of Amazons, D. They were defeated, but realized they had fought their own crew members Correct Option: A
Question 4: What was the name of the seer who was cursed by Zeus and provided the Argonauts with crucial advice? Options: A. Phineas, B. Orpheus, C. Hercules, D. Castor Correct Option: A
Question 5: What was the terrifying trial that the Argonauts had to overcome, as warned by Phineas? Options: A. The Symplegades, a pair of clashing rocks, B. The mouth of hell, C. The island of the bloodthirsty Amazons, D. The Mount of Bears Correct Option: A
Question 6: What can be inferred about Jason's leadership skills based on his actions throughout the story? Options: A. He is a strong and decisive leader, B. He is often distracted and impulsive, C. He relies heavily on the advice of others, D. He is unwilling to take risks Correct Option: B
Question 7: How did the Argonauts manage to navigate through the Symplegades? Options: A. They used their combined strength to push the rocks apart, B. They released a single dove and sped through in its wake, C. They sailed around the rocks, D. They waited for a storm to pass Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was the ultimate goal of Jason's journey, and what was the promised reward? Options: A. To retrieve the golden fleece and claim the throne of Thessaly, B. To defeat the monsters on the Mount of Bears and gain fame, C. To charm the harpies surrounding Phineas and gain wisdom, D. To cross the seas to Colchis and find treasure Correct Option: A
Question 9: What can be concluded about the challenges faced by the Argonauts and how they overcame them? Options: A. The Argonauts faced numerous challenges, but their combined strength and cunning allowed them to overcome them, B. The Argonauts faced few challenges, but their lack of leadership and planning hindered their progress, C. The Argonauts faced only physical challenges, which they overcame through brute force, D. The Argonauts faced only moral challenges, which they overcame through their values Correct Option: A
Question 10: What was the consequence of Jason's decision to sail on without Hercules after his squire was abducted? Options: A. The crew was able to reach Colchis more quickly, B. The crew was put in greater danger without Hercules' strength, C. The crew was unaffected by Hercules' absence, D. The crew was able to find the golden fleece more easily Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content and options. However, based on the overall intent and topic, I would say that the most similar generated MCQ is not present in the list.

However, if I had to choose one that is somewhat related to the topic of the Argonauts, I would say that Question 8 is the closest match. It mentions Jason's journey and his goal, which is related to the context in which the Argonauts are mentioned.

But since none of the generated MCQs directly ask about the origin of the Argonauts' name, I couldn't find a perfect match.

**Transcript**:
Hercules, 
the strongest man alive with a mighty heart to match. Orpheus, 
charmer of nature and master of music. Castor and Pollux, 
the twin tricksters hatched from an egg. The Boreads, 
sons of the North Wind who could hurtle through the air. For untold times 
these heroes had roamed ancient Greece, creating new legends wherever they went. But none of their adventures 
was so great as when they joined forces for the sake of a young man named Jason. Years before, Jason’s uncle Pelias 
had ruthlessly usurped the throne of Thessaly 
from Jason’s grandfather. When Jason returned 
to his father’s stolen court, the cowardly king 
set him a seemingly impossible task: cross the teeming seas to Colchis, and steal 
the golden fleece of a flying ram under King Aeetes’ nose. If Jason retrieved the Fleece, Pelias promised to relinquish the throne. Touched by his heroic mission, the Gods spread Jason’s call for help, and soon 
he had assembled a not-so-motley crew. These heroes, alongside countless sailors,
soothsayers, and rebel demigods, named themselves 
the Argonauts after their sturdy ship. But the path ahead 
was marked with untold terrors– enough to test even the fiercest heroes. Their first stop was Lemnos, an isle of women 
who had killed all the island’s men. As punishment, Aphrodite had cursed them
with a sickening stench– but that didn’t stop Jason 
fathering twins with the queen. The rest of the crew also found themselves
embroiled in new romances; until Hercules chastised them 
for not behaving like heroes. Eventually, 
they sailed on to the Mount of Bears, an island where a group of ancient, 
six-armed monsters lived alongside the peaceful Doliones. While the clan welcomed 
the Argonauts with open arms, the monsters surged down 
from the mountains and hurled rocks at the docked ship. Hercules held them off single-handedly, before his comrades joined the fray. Bolstered by their victory, 
the triumphant heroes sailed onward– only to be blown back 
to the island several stormy nights later. In the tempest, the Doliones 
thought these new arrivals invaders. The Argonauts were similarly unaware 
of their surroundings, and fought blunderingly in the dark, 
slaying wave after wave of foe. But the morning light 
revealed a horrible truth: their victims 
were none other than their previous hosts. Yet again, Jason had allowed the crew 
to be distracted, this time at a terrible cost. Ashamed at his conduct, he resolved 
to focus only on the Fleece, but even this haste proved ruinous. When Hercules’ squire 
was abducted by a water nymph, Jason sailed on– oblivious to the absence 
of his most powerful crewmate. The remaining Argonauts 
continued their quest, until stopping at the sight of an old man 
surrounded by a swirl of harpies. This was Phineas, 
a seer cursed by Zeus to endure 
old age, blindness, and endless torture for giving away 
his prophecies. Moved by his plight, 
the wind brothers set upon the flock, providing Phineas 
with a brief respite from his punishment. In return, the seer told them how to overcome
the terrifying trial that lay ahead: the Symplegades, a pair clashing rocks 
that reduced ships to splinters. But first, the Argonauts would have to maneuver 
past the mouth of hell, around the island 
of the bloodthirsty Amazons, and under psychedelic skies. These adventures cost the crew 
both in men and morale– and some feared 
they might be losing their minds. Upon reaching the clashing rocks, 
the exhausted crew quaked with fear. But Phineas’ advice rang in their heads. The Argonauts released a single dove and sped through in its wake 
to emerge unscathed. With this narrow escape, the Argonauts 
finally had Colchis in their sights. Yet while Jason rested 
and celebrated with his crew, he could feel his time 
among them was drawing to a close. As the fleece gleamed in his mind, he knew 
he would have to retrieve it alone. But he could not guess 
that this final task would have the most horrible price of all.

Options: A. Crete, B. Thessaly, C. Colchis, D. The Boreads
Correct Option: C

to his father’s stolen court, the cowardly king 
set him a seemingly impossible task: cross the teeming seas to Colchis, and steal 
the golden fleece of a flying ram under King Aeetes’ nose. If Jason retrieved the Fleece, Pelias promised to relinquish the throne. Touched by his heroic mission, the Gods spread Jason’s call for help, and soon 
he had assembled a not-so-motley crew. These heroes, alongside countless sailors,
soothsayers, and rebel demigods, named themselves 
the Argonauts after their sturdy ship. But the path ahead 
was marked with untold terrors– enough to test even the fiercest heroes. Their first stop was Lemnos, an isle of women 
who had killed all the island’s men. As punishment, Aphrodite had cursed them
with a sickening stench– but that didn’t stop Jason 
fathering twins with the queen. The rest of the crew also found themselves
embroiled in new romances; until Hercules chastised them 
for not behaving like heroes. Eventually, 
they sailed on to the Mount of Bears, an island where a group of ancient, 
six-armed monsters lived alongside the peaceful Doliones. While the clan welcomed 
the Argonauts with open arms, the monsters surged down 
from the mountains and hurled rocks at the docked ship. Hercules held them off single-handedly, before his comrades joined the fray. Bolstered by their victory, 
the triumphant heroes sailed onward– only to be blown back 
to the island several stormy nights later. In the tempest, the Doliones 
thought these new arrivals invaders. The Argonauts were similarly unaware 
of their surroundings, and fought blunderingly in the dark, 
slaying wave after wave of foe. But the morning light 
revealed a horrible truth: their victims 
were none other than their previous hosts. Yet again, Jason had allowed the crew 
to be distracted, this time at a terrible cost. Ashamed at his conduct, he resolved 
to focus only on the Fleece, but even this haste proved ruinous. When Hercules’ squire 
was abducted by a water nymph, Jason sailed on– oblivious to the absence 
of his most powerful crewmate. The remaining Argonauts 
continued their quest, until stopping at the sight of an old man 
surrounded by a swirl of harpies. This was Phineas, 
a seer cursed by Zeus to endure 
old age, blindness, and endless torture for giving away 
his prophecies. Moved by his plight, 
the wind brothers set upon the flock, providing Phineas 
with a brief respite from his punishment. In return, the seer told them how to overcome
the terrifying trial that lay ahead: the Symplegades, a pair clashing rocks 
that reduced ships to splinters. But first, the Argonauts would have to maneuver 
past the mouth of hell, around the island 
of the bloodthirsty Amazons, and under psychedelic skies. These adventures cost the crew 
both in men and morale– and some feared 
they might be losing their minds. Upon reaching the clashing rocks, 
the exhausted crew quaked with fear. But Phineas’ advice rang in their heads. The Argonauts released a single dove and sped through in its wake 
to emerge unscathed. With this narrow escape, the Argonauts 
finally had Colchis in their sights. Yet while Jason rested 
and celebrated with his crew, he could feel his time 
among them was drawing to a close. As the fleece gleamed in his mind, he knew 
he would have to retrieve it alone. But he could not guess 
that this final task would have the most horrible price of all.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The island of Lemnos was inhabited by:
Options: A. Ruthless giants, B. Foul-smelling murderers, C. Vengeful gods, D. Bloodthirsty giants
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who was the young man that the heroes joined forces for, and what was his mission? Options: A. Jason, to cross the seas to Colchis and steal the golden fleece, B. Hercules, to defeat the monsters on the Mount of Bears, C. Orpheus, to charm the harpies surrounding Phineas, D. Castor, to retrieve the throne of Thessaly Correct Option: A
Question 2: What was the curse placed upon the women of Lemnos by Aphrodite? Options: A. They were turned into monsters, B. They were cursed with a sickening stench, C. They were made to be infertile, D. They were forced to live on the Mount of Bears Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the outcome of the Argonauts' battle with the Doliones, and what did they realize the next morning? Options: A. They emerged victorious, but realized they had fought their previous hosts, B. They were defeated, but realized they had fought a group of monsters, C. They emerged victorious, but realized they had fought a group of Amazons, D. They were defeated, but realized they had fought their own crew members Correct Option: A
Question 4: What was the name of the seer who was cursed by Zeus and provided the Argonauts with crucial advice? Options: A. Phineas, B. Orpheus, C. Hercules, D. Castor Correct Option: A
Question 5: What was the terrifying trial that the Argonauts had to overcome, as warned by Phineas? Options: A. The Symplegades, a pair of clashing rocks, B. The mouth of hell, C. The island of the bloodthirsty Amazons, D. The Mount of Bears Correct Option: A
Question 6: What can be inferred about Jason's leadership skills based on his actions throughout the story? Options: A. He is a strong and decisive leader, B. He is often distracted and impulsive, C. He relies heavily on the advice of others, D. He is unwilling to take risks Correct Option: B
Question 7: How did the Argonauts manage to navigate through the Symplegades? Options: A. They used their combined strength to push the rocks apart, B. They released a single dove and sped through in its wake, C. They sailed around the rocks, D. They waited for a storm to pass Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was the ultimate goal of Jason's journey, and what was the promised reward? Options: A. To retrieve the golden fleece and claim the throne of Thessaly, B. To defeat the monsters on the Mount of Bears and gain fame, C. To charm the harpies surrounding Phineas and gain wisdom, D. To cross the seas to Colchis and find treasure Correct Option: A
Question 9: What can be concluded about the challenges faced by the Argonauts and how they overcame them? Options: A. The Argonauts faced numerous challenges, but their combined strength and cunning allowed them to overcome them, B. The Argonauts faced few challenges, but their lack of leadership and planning hindered their progress, C. The Argonauts faced only physical challenges, which they overcame through brute force, D. The Argonauts faced only moral challenges, which they overcame through their values Correct Option: A
Question 10: What was the consequence of Jason's decision to sail on without Hercules after his squire was abducted? Options: A. The crew was able to reach Colchis more quickly, B. The crew was put in greater danger without Hercules' strength, C. The crew was unaffected by Hercules' absence, D. The crew was able to find the golden fleece more easily Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question asks about the curse placed upon the women of Lemnos by Aphrodite, which is directly related to the ground truth MCQ that asks about the inhabitants of the island of Lemnos. The correct option in Question 2, "They were cursed with a sickening stench," provides additional context about the women of Lemnos, who are described as "foul-smelling murderers" in the correct option of the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Hercules, 
the strongest man alive with a mighty heart to match. Orpheus, 
charmer of nature and master of music. Castor and Pollux, 
the twin tricksters hatched from an egg. The Boreads, 
sons of the North Wind who could hurtle through the air. For untold times 
these heroes had roamed ancient Greece, creating new legends wherever they went. But none of their adventures 
was so great as when they joined forces for the sake of a young man named Jason. Years before, Jason’s uncle Pelias 
had ruthlessly usurped the throne of Thessaly 
from Jason’s grandfather. When Jason returned 
to his father’s stolen court, the cowardly king 
set him a seemingly impossible task: cross the teeming seas to Colchis, and steal 
the golden fleece of a flying ram under King Aeetes’ nose. If Jason retrieved the Fleece, Pelias promised to relinquish the throne. Touched by his heroic mission, the Gods spread Jason’s call for help, and soon 
he had assembled a not-so-motley crew. These heroes, alongside countless sailors,
soothsayers, and rebel demigods, named themselves 
the Argonauts after their sturdy ship. But the path ahead 
was marked with untold terrors– enough to test even the fiercest heroes. Their first stop was Lemnos, an isle of women 
who had killed all the island’s men. As punishment, Aphrodite had cursed them
with a sickening stench– but that didn’t stop Jason 
fathering twins with the queen. The rest of the crew also found themselves
embroiled in new romances; until Hercules chastised them 
for not behaving like heroes. Eventually, 
they sailed on to the Mount of Bears, an island where a group of ancient, 
six-armed monsters lived alongside the peaceful Doliones. While the clan welcomed 
the Argonauts with open arms, the monsters surged down 
from the mountains and hurled rocks at the docked ship. Hercules held them off single-handedly, before his comrades joined the fray. Bolstered by their victory, 
the triumphant heroes sailed onward– only to be blown back 
to the island several stormy nights later. In the tempest, the Doliones 
thought these new arrivals invaders. The Argonauts were similarly unaware 
of their surroundings, and fought blunderingly in the dark, 
slaying wave after wave of foe. But the morning light 
revealed a horrible truth: their victims 
were none other than their previous hosts. Yet again, Jason had allowed the crew 
to be distracted, this time at a terrible cost. Ashamed at his conduct, he resolved 
to focus only on the Fleece, but even this haste proved ruinous. When Hercules’ squire 
was abducted by a water nymph, Jason sailed on– oblivious to the absence 
of his most powerful crewmate. The remaining Argonauts 
continued their quest, until stopping at the sight of an old man 
surrounded by a swirl of harpies. This was Phineas, 
a seer cursed by Zeus to endure 
old age, blindness, and endless torture for giving away 
his prophecies. Moved by his plight, 
the wind brothers set upon the flock, providing Phineas 
with a brief respite from his punishment. In return, the seer told them how to overcome
the terrifying trial that lay ahead: the Symplegades, a pair clashing rocks 
that reduced ships to splinters. But first, the Argonauts would have to maneuver 
past the mouth of hell, around the island 
of the bloodthirsty Amazons, and under psychedelic skies. These adventures cost the crew 
both in men and morale– and some feared 
they might be losing their minds. Upon reaching the clashing rocks, 
the exhausted crew quaked with fear. But Phineas’ advice rang in their heads. The Argonauts released a single dove and sped through in its wake 
to emerge unscathed. With this narrow escape, the Argonauts 
finally had Colchis in their sights. Yet while Jason rested 
and celebrated with his crew, he could feel his time 
among them was drawing to a close. As the fleece gleamed in his mind, he knew 
he would have to retrieve it alone. But he could not guess 
that this final task would have the most horrible price of all.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: On the quest, Hercules lost his squire to:
Options: A. A water nymph, B. A pair of clashing rocks, C. Giants, D. Harpies
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Despite a serene sunset 
on the Dnipro river, the mood is tense for the 
Zaporozhian Cossacks. The year is 1676, and the Treaty of 
Żurawno has officially ended hostilities between the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth
and the Ottoman Empire. But as Stepan and his men ride 
towards their stronghold, peace is far from their minds. Having made their home in the Wild Fields 
north of the Black Sea, these cossacks— derived from a Turkic 
word for "free man"— are renowned as one of Europe’s most 
formidable military forces. Composed of hunters, fishermen, 
nomads and outlaws, the Cossacks found freedom in these 
fertile unclaimed lands. Yet this freedom has proven increasingly 
difficult to maintain. Their decades-long strategy of shifting 
alliances between Poland and Moscow has led to the partitioning 
of their lands. In a desperate bid to reclaim independence
and reunite the fractured Cossack state, their most recent leader, hetman Petro 
Doroshenko allied with the Ottoman Empire. This alliance successfully freed the 
Zaporozhian Cossacks in the west from Polish dominion, but 
their victory was a bitter one. Doroshenko’s Ottoman allies 
ravaged the countryside, carrying off peasants into slavery. And outrage at allying with Muslims 
against fellow Christians cost him any remaining local support. Now, with Doroshenko deposed and exiled, the Cossacks are at odds, disagreeing 
on what their next move should be. Until then, Stepan must keep order. With his musket and curved saber, 
he cuts an imposing figure. He surveys his battalion of 180 men. Most are Orthodox Christians 
and speak a Slavic language that will become modern Ukrainian. But there are also Greeks, Tatars, 
and even some Mongolian Kalmyks, many with different opinions 
on recent events. Officially, all of Stepan’s men have 
sworn to uphold the Cossack code by undergoing seven years of military 
training and remaining unmarried. In practice, some are part-timers, holding
more closely to their own traditions, and maintaining families in nearby 
villages, outside Cossack lands. Thankfully, the tenuous peace is not 
broken before they reach the Sich— the center of Cossack military life. Currently located at Chortomlyk, the Sich’s location shifts with 
the tide of military action. The settlement is remarkably well-
organized, with administrative buildings, officers’ quarters, and even schools, 
as Cossacks prize literacy. Stepan and his men make their way 
to the barracks where they live and train alongside several other 
battalions or kurins, all of which make up a several 
hundred man regiment. Inside, the men dine on dried fish, 
sheep’s cheese, and salted pork fat— along with plenty of wine. Stepan instructs his friend Yuri to 
lighten the mood with his bandura. But before long, an argument 
has broken out. One of his men has raised 
a toast to Doroshenko. Stepan cuts him off. The room is silent until he raises 
his own toast to Ivan Sirko, the new hetman who favors an alliance 
with Moscow against the Turks. Stepan plans to support him, and 
he expects his men to do the same. Suddenly, one of Sirko’s men rushes in, calling an emergency Rada, 
or general council meeting. Stepan and the others make their 
way towards the church square— the center of Sich life. Ivan Sirko welcomes the confused 
crowd with exciting news— scouts have located a large Ottoman 
camp completely vulnerable on one side. Sirko vows that tomorrow, they will 
ride against their common enemy, defend the Cossacks’ autonomy, 
and bring unity to the Wild Fields. As the men cheer in unison, Stepan is relieved at their renewed 
sense of brotherhood. Over the next 200 years, these 
freedom fighters would take on many foes. And tragically, they would eventually become the 
oppressive hand of the Russian government they once opposed. But today, these 17th century Cossacks are remembered for their spirit of 
independence and defiance. As the Russian painter 
Ilya Repin once said: “No people in the world held freedom, 
equality, and fraternity so deeply.”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the linguistic origin of the word ‘cossack’?
Options: A. Slavic, B. Turkic, C. Germanic
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the origin of the word "Cossack"? Options: A. From a Polish word for "warrior", B. From a Turkic word for "free man", C. From a Russian word for "soldier", D. From a Ukrainian word for "nomad" Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the outcome of Hetman Petro Doroshenko's alliance with the Ottoman Empire for the Zaporozhian Cossacks? Options: A. They gained control over the entire Wild Fields region, B. They were freed from Polish dominion in the west, but the Ottomans ravaged the countryside, C. They were completely defeated by the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, D. They were forced to surrender to the Russian government Correct Option: B
Question 3: Who is the new hetman that favors an alliance with Moscow against the Turks? Options: A. Petro Doroshenko, B. Ivan Sirko, C. Stepan, D. Yuri Correct Option: B
Question 4: What are the requirements of the Cossack code that Stepan's men have sworn to uphold? Options: A. Undergoing seven years of military training and remaining unmarried, B. Holding their own traditions and maintaining families, C. Being literate and educated, D. Being loyal only to the Ottoman Empire Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the name of the center of Cossack military life that shifts with the tide of military action? Options: A. Chortomlyk, B. Sich, C. Wild Fields, D. Zaporozhian Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the purpose of the bandura in the context of the story? Options: A. To symbolize Cossack military power, B. To lighten the mood, C. To communicate among Cossacks, D. To remind Cossacks of their traditions and heritage Correct Option: B
Question 7: What causes tension among Stepan's men during dinner? Options: A. Disagreement over the Cossack code, B. Disagreement over the alliance with the Ottoman Empire, C. Disagreement over the leadership of Ivan Sirko, D. A toast to Petro Doroshenko Correct Option: D
Question 8: What decision is made at the emergency Rada meeting called by Ivan Sirko? Options: A. To surrender to the Ottoman Empire, B. To ally with the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, C. To ride against the Ottoman Empire and defend Cossack autonomy, D. To abandon their stronghold and flee Correct Option: C
Question 9: How does the Cossacks' relationship with the Russian government change over time? Options: A. They remain allies throughout history, B. They are initially enemies, but eventually become allies, C. They transition from being freedom fighters to becoming the oppressive hand of the government, D. They maintain a neutral distance from the Russian government Correct Option: C
Question 10: According to Ilya Repin, what values did the Cossacks hold deeply? Options: A. Loyalty, duty, and obedience, B. Freedom, equality, and fraternity, C. Honor, courage, and strength, D. Tradition, heritage, and culture Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 1: What is the origin of the word "Cossack"? Options: A. From a Polish word for "warrior", B. From a Turkic word for "free man", C. From a Russian word for "soldier", D. From a Ukrainian word for "nomad" Correct Option: B**

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (asking about the origin of the word "Cossack"), options (providing multiple possible origins), and content (identifying the correct origin as Turkic).

The index of the most similar generated MCQ is: **1**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
Despite a serene sunset 
on the Dnipro river, the mood is tense for the 
Zaporozhian Cossacks. The year is 1676, and the Treaty of 
Żurawno has officially ended hostilities between the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth
and the Ottoman Empire. But as Stepan and his men ride 
towards their stronghold, peace is far from their minds. Having made their home in the Wild Fields 
north of the Black Sea, these cossacks— derived from a Turkic 
word for "free man"— are renowned as one of Europe’s most 
formidable military forces. Composed of hunters, fishermen, 
nomads and outlaws, the Cossacks found freedom in these 
fertile unclaimed lands. Yet this freedom has proven increasingly 
difficult to maintain. Their decades-long strategy of shifting 
alliances between Poland and Moscow has led to the partitioning 
of their lands. In a desperate bid to reclaim independence
and reunite the fractured Cossack state, their most recent leader, hetman Petro 
Doroshenko allied with the Ottoman Empire. This alliance successfully freed the 
Zaporozhian Cossacks in the west from Polish dominion, but 
their victory was a bitter one. Doroshenko’s Ottoman allies 
ravaged the countryside, carrying off peasants into slavery. And outrage at allying with Muslims 
against fellow Christians cost him any remaining local support. Now, with Doroshenko deposed and exiled, the Cossacks are at odds, disagreeing 
on what their next move should be. Until then, Stepan must keep order. With his musket and curved saber, 
he cuts an imposing figure. He surveys his battalion of 180 men. Most are Orthodox Christians 
and speak a Slavic language that will become modern Ukrainian. But there are also Greeks, Tatars, 
and even some Mongolian Kalmyks, many with different opinions 
on recent events. Officially, all of Stepan’s men have 
sworn to uphold the Cossack code by undergoing seven years of military 
training and remaining unmarried. In practice, some are part-timers, holding
more closely to their own traditions, and maintaining families in nearby 
villages, outside Cossack lands. Thankfully, the tenuous peace is not 
broken before they reach the Sich— the center of Cossack military life. Currently located at Chortomlyk, the Sich’s location shifts with 
the tide of military action. The settlement is remarkably well-
organized, with administrative buildings, officers’ quarters, and even schools, 
as Cossacks prize literacy. Stepan and his men make their way 
to the barracks where they live and train alongside several other 
battalions or kurins, all of which make up a several 
hundred man regiment. Inside, the men dine on dried fish, 
sheep’s cheese, and salted pork fat— along with plenty of wine. Stepan instructs his friend Yuri to 
lighten the mood with his bandura. But before long, an argument 
has broken out. One of his men has raised 
a toast to Doroshenko. Stepan cuts him off. The room is silent until he raises 
his own toast to Ivan Sirko, the new hetman who favors an alliance 
with Moscow against the Turks. Stepan plans to support him, and 
he expects his men to do the same. Suddenly, one of Sirko’s men rushes in, calling an emergency Rada, 
or general council meeting. Stepan and the others make their 
way towards the church square— the center of Sich life. Ivan Sirko welcomes the confused 
crowd with exciting news— scouts have located a large Ottoman 
camp completely vulnerable on one side. Sirko vows that tomorrow, they will 
ride against their common enemy, defend the Cossacks’ autonomy, 
and bring unity to the Wild Fields. As the men cheer in unison, Stepan is relieved at their renewed 
sense of brotherhood. Over the next 200 years, these 
freedom fighters would take on many foes. And tragically, they would eventually become the 
oppressive hand of the Russian government they once opposed. But today, these 17th century Cossacks are remembered for their spirit of 
independence and defiance. As the Russian painter 
Ilya Repin once said: “No people in the world held freedom, 
equality, and fraternity so deeply.”

Question: What is a cossack leader called?

Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Despite a serene sunset 
on the Dnipro river, the mood is tense for the 
Zaporozhian Cossacks. The year is 1676, and the Treaty of 
Żurawno has officially ended hostilities between the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth
and the Ottoman Empire. But as Stepan and his men ride 
towards their stronghold, peace is far from their minds. Having made their home in the Wild Fields 
north of the Black Sea, these cossacks— derived from a Turkic 
word for "free man"— are renowned as one of Europe’s most 
formidable military forces. Composed of hunters, fishermen, 
nomads and outlaws, the Cossacks found freedom in these 
fertile unclaimed lands. Yet this freedom has proven increasingly 
difficult to maintain. Their decades-long strategy of shifting 
alliances between Poland and Moscow has led to the partitioning 
of their lands. In a desperate bid to reclaim independence
and reunite the fractured Cossack state, their most recent leader, hetman Petro 
Doroshenko allied with the Ottoman Empire. This alliance successfully freed the 
Zaporozhian Cossacks in the west from Polish dominion, but 
their victory was a bitter one. Doroshenko’s Ottoman allies 
ravaged the countryside, carrying off peasants into slavery. And outrage at allying with Muslims 
against fellow Christians cost him any remaining local support. Now, with Doroshenko deposed and exiled, the Cossacks are at odds, disagreeing 
on what their next move should be. Until then, Stepan must keep order. With his musket and curved saber, 
he cuts an imposing figure. He surveys his battalion of 180 men. Most are Orthodox Christians 
and speak a Slavic language that will become modern Ukrainian. But there are also Greeks, Tatars, 
and even some Mongolian Kalmyks, many with different opinions 
on recent events. Officially, all of Stepan’s men have 
sworn to uphold the Cossack code by undergoing seven years of military 
training and remaining unmarried. In practice, some are part-timers, holding
more closely to their own traditions, and maintaining families in nearby 
villages, outside Cossack lands. Thankfully, the tenuous peace is not 
broken before they reach the Sich— the center of Cossack military life. Currently located at Chortomlyk, the Sich’s location shifts with 
the tide of military action. The settlement is remarkably well-
organized, with administrative buildings, officers’ quarters, and even schools, 
as Cossacks prize literacy. Stepan and his men make their way 
to the barracks where they live and train alongside several other 
battalions or kurins, all of which make up a several 
hundred man regiment. Inside, the men dine on dried fish, 
sheep’s cheese, and salted pork fat— along with plenty of wine. Stepan instructs his friend Yuri to 
lighten the mood with his bandura. But before long, an argument 
has broken out. One of his men has raised 
a toast to Doroshenko. Stepan cuts him off. The room is silent until he raises 
his own toast to Ivan Sirko, the new hetman who favors an alliance 
with Moscow against the Turks. Stepan plans to support him, and 
he expects his men to do the same. Suddenly, one of Sirko’s men rushes in, calling an emergency Rada, 
or general council meeting. Stepan and the others make their 
way towards the church square— the center of Sich life. Ivan Sirko welcomes the confused 
crowd with exciting news— scouts have located a large Ottoman 
camp completely vulnerable on one side. Sirko vows that tomorrow, they will 
ride against their common enemy, defend the Cossacks’ autonomy, 
and bring unity to the Wild Fields. As the men cheer in unison, Stepan is relieved at their renewed 
sense of brotherhood. Over the next 200 years, these 
freedom fighters would take on many foes. And tragically, they would eventually become the 
oppressive hand of the Russian government they once opposed. But today, these 17th century Cossacks are remembered for their spirit of 
independence and defiance. As the Russian painter 
Ilya Repin once said: “No people in the world held freedom, 
equality, and fraternity so deeply.”

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The cossacks spoke a precursor to what modern-day language?
Options: A. Russian, B. Ukrainian, C. Polish
Correct Option: B

Question 2: What was the outcome of Hetman Petro Doroshenko's alliance with the Ottoman Empire for the Zaporozhian Cossacks? Options: A. They gained control over the entire Wild Fields region, B. They were freed from Polish dominion in the west, but the Ottomans ravaged the countryside, C. They were completely defeated by the Polish-Lithuanian Commonwealth, D. They were forced to surrender to the Russian government Correct Option: B
